author: BatMeckley
content: Reference tracks are really good as a tool while you’re learning, be it mixing or producing. Trying to match a song you dig as close as you can really works out the “this is what I want to hear, how do I get there” muscle. But after putting together a few hundred songs that way, I’ve found it better to go with your heart vs constantly referencing Teenage Dream every 10 minutes to figure out where your kick sits. Be an A grade you, not a C grade Serban. (After you’ve put in the work to build up your skill set of course)

author: Adam Thein
content:
Maybe I can try and distill down some suggestions from the conversation for avoiding the pit of despair while referencing:

1) Don't get stuck going back and forth constantly between your mix and your reference - you can get trapped in a loop

2) Think critically about what elements are in the reference track versus what you are working with - is there enough overlap in production and arrangement that makes this a good reference?

3) Focus on the broad strokes - I've seen it described on the server before as "where the edges are" - how wide is the mix, where's the top end sitting, where's the low end sitting, and what are the elements dominating those frequency spectrums

4) Careful not to shy away from what the track wants to be to make it conform to the bell curve

I'm probably missing a lot of things but here's a start?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Here’s the one other thing about Serban that I think is obvious, but seemingly overlooked a lot

There’s a trade off between dynamic control/having things locked in place, and allowing things to be wilder. Mixes where things are locked in place sound more similar everywhere, they are in a sense robust. Mixes with braver dynamic or EQ choices can be much more exciting under ideal conditions, but do less well at the edges of the bell curve (mono overhead speaker at the supermarket for example)

Serban’s mixes are very locked in place, dynamically and from a frequency point of view and so he has great translation. I rarely find it to get in the way of the song, but some of my mixer friends will go to the mat about how it could have been so much more …. And maybe they’re right

But if you win the race, and the song comes through then how much more do you need to win it by? His mixes do the job of getting pop songs into my ears, and give A&R confidence and comfort, a lot to like …

author: Brodie Stewart
content:
I’ve found that as my monitoring environment has improved over the years, and the more familiar I become with it, I find myself using references less and less. I just mix music the way my ears want to hear it (which thankfully pairs to the speaker choice well!).

Every now and then, if I’ve lost perspective or there’s a translation issue I might pull in a reference for a reality check. Otherwise a reference is handy for broad stroke “concepts” (E.g distorted vocals, or tight dry drums etc.) and I’ve learned not to take them too literally - otherwise you end up going down the rabbit hole and inevitably chasing your tail to a worse mix 😞

author: Zack Hames
content:
The technical skills are all more or less the same, but you’ll be doing different tasks. Editing VO quickly, using Frames for your grid / worrying about timecode, importing AAF or OMF files from video editors via Import Session Data in PT. It’s more about understanding the expectations and workflow for Post Production that has a learning curve compared to album production.

Oh, and understanding ISDN and Source Connect to connect with other studios, hating when people send you VO files that are in 44.1 and poorly processed when you specifically asked for raw/48k/24 bit, video people thinking they can do audio, replacing shitty sfx they rip from YouTube with decent ones, and being a wizard with Izotope RX suite to remove every little noise, crackle, train, plane, fountain, waterfall, wind, you name it, are some of the things you’ll spend your time doing that maybe you wouldn’t if you were producing music. It keeps me very fresh in pro tools which is nice and I’ve learned a lot about working insanely fast and communicating with clients as well as instilling confidence. It’s a really interesting field and the $$$ is great.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
first off, if it sounds good, do it. i know that starts to sound like an annoying cliche, but it's ALWAYS good to re-remind yourself. there are no rules with this shit and the more your learn about the technical side the LESS you should rely on it. because your ears are getting better and thus you should be trusting them more.

the phase shift from a bell curve is much more subtle compared to HP and LP filtering, so it tends to add back in much better when used in parallel. also there are plenty situations where you might actually *like* the phase shift, where you're boosting something like upper mid range and you get just a teeny bit of blur in the low mids. there are good articles online that graph it, but i'd say just be mindful of phase by flipping the parallel channel and seeing what it does. and trust ya ears and just do what sounds good to you!

author: Slow Hand
content:
I do a version of this a lot when mixing. If I feel like a key element has gotten way too many layers of paint I duplicate the channel, strip off the plugins, try again and then A/B against my original to verify that I've not lost anything vital. 

Usually I'm able to recreate the vibe I need with fewer steps once I can see what's working and it has far better definition because there's less crufty processing happening.

author: Josh Bowman
content: Spent an hour this morning listening to mixes and reference tracks on Audeze LCD-5's MM-500s, LCD-X, LCD2, and Focal Clear MGs. After going back and forth and comparing for a while and taking breaks, I liked the LCD-X the least, just sounded weird and unnatural to me in the mid range, LCD-5s were my second least favourite which was surprising. I found Hats and things in that range had a really weird un-natural sound to them.. not sure how else to describe it. Just not for me. The Clear MG and MM-500s both sounded great, altho when i listened to some "thicker/warmer" mixes i'd done on the Focals, it felt like I would have scooped my mix too much if i'd been on them, because they were pretty full sounding/a bit boomy in the low mids/bottom, where the mixes sounded how i intended on the MM-500s. If i was buying with the intent to use them for production, or as a secondary reference, i'd probably go with the clears because they sound fun and were really comfy, have a bit more high end and bottom end.. but the mannys seemed flatter/sounded more natural in the bottom and top and more like what i'd want to hear while mixing i think.  Found a pair of demo MM-500s for a slight discount and pulled the trigger on them just now. Can followup in a week to see if after trying to mix on them i have buyers remorse or not 😂

author: Slow Hand
content:
One habit that I've picked up using Ableton that's really handy is doing all of my volume rides and mute automation with a *utility* plugin. This gives me a few advantages:

1. I can place the rides/mutes exactly where I want in the signal path (into a compressor, before a verb, after a verb, etc)

2. I can easily enable/disable the automation if I want to A/B or simplify while solving another problem.

3. My faders are left solely for global level changes and I can easily mute the channel without mute automation turning it back on/off.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Maybe I'm alone here, but does anyone else dislike the sound of clippers? Especially on the master buss. I hear it all over contemporary records and just don't care for the aesthetic.

Maybe I'm doing it wrong, but it always results in things sounding mush-y or smeared. The only amount that I like is barely perceptible, at which point I find myself wondering why bother at all(?). Whenever I try put it on a mix I eventually A/B it later and find myself liking the un-clipped version.

The only reliable usage I've found is on percussion that's very transient and very noise-y. Like a hand clap. It helps me to get the absolute level down, while boosting the apparent loudness.

Don't get me wrong, I love distortion, but I'm not a fan of that particular flavor.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Hey!

I have it on my mix print track (I’m old school like that), along with an instance of Pro-Q3 and iZotope Insight. These three are always open on a second screen to my side. I have Tonal Balance set to the Fine mode, with the Modern curve preset, and with 5 second averaging instead of the default 10. I mostly just check it once I have a mix pretty much put together to see if I’m missing anything as a dummy check, but I’ll also look at it when comparing to a ref or playing with kick/bass levels. Sometimes it’s also helpful to find a spot for a final element or two I’m trying to shoehorn into a dense arrangement—but for that I usually just pull up Spectre and push frequencies around until things sound good. (The instance of Pro-Q3 is for seeing more fine detail, and Insjght I’m just using to measure loudness.)

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
i started doing this at the beginning of the year and was probably the biggest improvement for the consistency of my mixes:

1) use _one to two_ reference track that i think the tonal balance is perfect (for me 7 rings by ariana grande lol)
2) have it in Adapter Metric AB looped at the chorus of that song and assign the A/B switch to a key command
3) hit the key command while your track is playing and reference a short 3 second burst than go back to your track

The only thing im listening for is stuff that is _completely_ out of whack that jumps out immediately. Like "WHOA there is _way_ too much 1k in my vocal" Anything more subtle is going to throw me down a rabbit hole of trying to match 2 completely different songs.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think it's important to recognize which "game" you're trying to play. Some people are playing the status game. Some people play the money game. Some people play the hit-making game. Some people play the artist/creativity/exploration game. Some people are playing the "I want to live in the woods and be left alone" game.

A big factor in stepping outside of these hierarchies is in your mindset. If you can be clear about what your actual values are then you will have a far easier time finding happiness and being satisfied leaving the other pursuits unrealized.

Then you can move laterally and pursue goals that are unique to you and that's probably the best thing that a lot of us have to offer the world: our opinionated, passion-driven, deep-diving life's work.

I mean hell, Spinoza was cast out from his Jewish community for his heretical and unconventional ideas about the nature of God. Now his *Ethics* is a beloved and wholly unique philosophical proof that endures and (to my knowledge) doesn't quite compare to anything else that people are doing in the field, even after several hundred years. He set himself apart by doing exactly what he wanted to. Shame he had to be exiled, though. 😭

author: Adam Thein
content:
I use it in the last 10% of the mix usually - when I'm at the OK my body is moving, the balances are close, I've got some automation to do but let's see where I'm at on Tonal Balance.  If my top end is generally trending too hot it probably means I've been working for too long and it's time for a break.  

I don't really use it while mixing, but more of a problem solver.  One thing I'll do is if I do see a clump of something somewhere I'll start muting tracks that are in that range to see if a single source is causing the lump or it it's a broader number of sources.  In that way it can be helpful to identify a certain instrument that isn't balanced well.

author: oaklandmatt

author: Matt Huber
content:
I communicate on the front end that I require that the tracks are printed with everything committed (w/ wet & dry option of lead vocal) along with detailed screenshots of the mix buss. If it sounds significantly different compared to the rough, I will ask for that to be addressed by the client before moving forward. 

This has made a massive difference for me productivity-wise. 

Like Chris, I also have things set up in my mix template to be able to build most non-PT sessions in 15 min or less.

author: Jonathan Jetter

I think mono *translation* (i.e. that the listener can follow the song- groove, melody, chord progression) is important-ish. But I also think it usually essentially happens by default, because kick/snare/bass/lead vocal are usually centered to begin with.

I don't spend a single moment worrying about mono *optimization*.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I use the TC clarity meter and am usually looking at an integrated level, in conjunction with the radar display which gives a visual representation of the track level. I don’t wait to measure the whole track, usually getting a handle of the overall integrated level across the loudest 30 seconds of the track gives a pretty accurate idea of how loud the track is. I’m also using the Klanghelm VU meter in RMS mode.  One other thing i’ve found really useful lately when mixing albums is using Izotope’s Tonal Balance plug to get a quick visual of the curve of the first few mixes after which I make preset based in those and use it as a quick ref when mixing the rest of the tracks. I’m finding a far more consistent result across a long project using this tool - especially when ears have gone a bit fuzzy

I haven't done much voice over myself but I've helped in a few VO translations and I find it super interesting that the voice levels vary  not just per  langauge but per accent. some regions naturally bring out specific sounds.

author: Marc
content:
For reference tracks — I was curious to compare two songs I love Bowie’s “Young Americans” and Springsteen “10th Avenue Freeze Out”. Similar instrumentation but the lesson for me was size and prominence of the different instruments. Bowie’s bass is way more prominent than Bruce. Bruce has the piano and guitar up front. Bowie’s has more delay and reverb. 

I think it reminds me I have to make more choices, and I also —(have to write better songs lol) — have to keep in mind when I use a reference track, that my tonal balance may be different or the vocal will sit differently if, say, my snare is way fatter/thinner than the reference track or my lead vocal is in a different octave register, which means the guitars are competing etc.

author: Mike Tierney
content: Damn we out here talkin about intonation systems? A lot of my bread and butter is contemporary classical/microtonal/experimental music and I'm in this world as both an engineer and often as a producer keeping track of how folks relate to the score and each other, take maps, etc. I tend to agree with some of the above that trying to chase down inharmonic relationships with EQ can make things worse, but I appreciate @LAPhill posting about bassoon/flute overtone series. @spectrummasters original question was about understanding the low mids and how they relate to EQing depending on the key; I think for me the way that understanding overtone series, tuning systems, and musical interactions in acoustic/orchestral instruments can relate to pop or rock mixing is like... Sometimes when I hear clashes between instruments playing thirds or clashes in the harmonic series and I'm trying to clear space in the mids/low mids, I do think about what instruments want to be occupying that space. So perhaps in the bassoon/flute example, I'd want the flute's fundamental to be stronger than the bassoon's first harmonic at C5, and that might look like EQing down the bassoon in the ranges of the flute's fundamentals, or in a rock mix looking at the bass's harmonics compared to where the lower range of the guitars are living. Obv instruments are moving and changing notes so none of this is surgical so much as the keys of the songs or the instruments' ranges might inform some general decisions about where to make space rather than just "cut 300 on the bass" or whatev

author: DarrenB
content: Another easy method for gainmatched reference is to use the Letimix Gainmatch plugin.  Load in your ref, mute the track.  Have your send Gainmatch on this and your receive on a listen bus (you'll want to make sure you avoid accidentally printing through it).  Gives a nice realtime feedback on where you're at level wise vs the ref (like Metric A/B), just another option I find handy if the sync or latch aspect of Metric A/B becomes cumbersome when you're not at the beginning of the timeline.

author: BillyC
content: At the risk of giving the least satisfying answer possible, without knowing or hearing what is intended in the music I think deep down we all know the answer to this is "when it just feels wrong." And personally I find using reference mixes to be a very slippery slope because they tend to make me question the record in front of me too analytically rather than react to its specific needs intuitively. I instead like to flash some references only at the beginning of the day just to remind myself what good records feel like in my chair before I start trying to make them. I find that whenever I'm asking myself the kind of questions like "do I have enough x, y, or z  frequency range" it's more of a warning sign that I need a perspective break because these questions hardly ever arise in a true creative flow. That's not to say I don't fall into this rabbit hole regularly, I'm just trying to practice what I suspect is a better way out of it!

author: Rob Domos
content: Voices in room do not sound like they are hitting a microphone. Think about the physics of sound for a second. High frequencies move in a laser beam shape and low frequencies move in a spherical shape. Nobody is ever turning with their ear facing 1 foot from a mouth that is laserbeaming high end into their ears. This is why you almost never hear saliva drips and lip smacking when in conversation and hear it constantly in recordings. This is also a big reason why the high end of most captures sounds so rough and edgy compared to real life. A lot of what I’m doing is going in and massaging that high end to take it from “this sounds like a mic capsule” to “this sounds like the person is in the room”

author: Zach Hughes
content: I recently revisited a mix I initially did in 2021 for an as of yet unreleased project. A folk / rock / americana track. My OG mix had this really aggressive edge to it that I kinda liked but it also felt way too scooped in the low mids. I checked out my old session and turns out I had cranked a ton of 8khz on the mixbus (a move I haven't felt compelled to do since 2021). Related I've been really enjoying thick / dense / full bodied mixes that still have excitement / edge up top especially for vocals and I had previously struggled to achieve a similar 'heft' in my own mixes compared to what I was hearing. I think in the past I was too quick to zap low mid resonances in my vocals / guitars. So I've been experimenting cutting less down around 200hz-600hz and emphasizing more. But then I felt I was losing some of that edge / excitement by see-sawing too much with the low mids relative to up top. I've found cutting some 170hz clears much of that up for me (like oh hey there's my snare or more room for kick / bass), I achieve the thickness above in that 200-600hz range and balance that with the excitement around ~8khz. Pushing and pulling.

author: Deleted User
content: Hey everyone, so a couple months ago I went to a workshop with one of the guys who worked on the loudness standard team for the european broadcast union and it was really interesting how he thinks about all that and how it translates to his mixing workflow in particular. So for those of you who don’t know in broadcast you have to hit a loudness of -23 LUFS +-1dBTP throughout the program. This is especially tricky with live program as you can imagine. But having this fixed loudness target also has a major advantage, it’s that you can have a fixed volume setting on your monitoring and with time you kinda know how loud you’re mixing compared to if you’re mixing for peak loudness, where you’ll always land on different loudness depending on the program. This was the first time I really understood the advantage of that way of working, because with time you’ll be so tuned to the loudness target you’ll be able to really intuit every move. And since -23 gives you boatloads of headroom you can really push things during mixing and then still get the density through clipping/limiting after that. It kinda ties in with what @Nomograph Mastering  was saying about fixed monitoring level. What do you guys think about that?

author: iampedrorafael
content: Same situation here, I used to avoid the "reality check" at the beginning of the mix so I could move primarily by feel. But then I was consistently making macro EQ moves on the mix bus in order to match the references a bit more at the end of the mix (typical 2db presence boost, maybe some 200-300hz scoop). This was a real pain in the ass, cause naturally things change a bit at that point and it's not an effective way to handle the problem. So now I have a preset for MetricAB with 8 reference tracks ready to go that I listen for short periods of time, sometimes 5 seconds or so, just to keep my years calibrated to what "normal" feels like in a macro-level. The fact that I don't need to leave the DAW environment (changing the visuals as well) to open a streaming app with different stimulus makes it really convenient to just do the right thing and compare apples to apples. The band-isolation mode really helps me to compare how different frequency ranges are moving also

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@bobby k other options I think about when I get into this situation: have the artist over and A/B things so you can show/explain the limitations presented to you. A stream with audiomovers and a facetime/zoom is often equally useful. You can also try and get an intermediary like management, label, or producer and team up with them (NOT to complain to them, but say "hey here are the challenges, can we collectively figure out how to get this over the finish line?").

Often times if you connect the artist (or whoever is giving notes) directly into your process as you're doing it, just feeling listened to and getting to make some decisions will help everything. If you've already done this and now you're going around in circles of indecision, maybe there's no fixing it. But if you're getting notes that don't make any sense, just find a way to let them make decisions in real time with you.

author: Adam Thein
content:
As someone who spends a lot of time in the no-crossfeed zone hearing a little shitty bandpassed speaker move a small amount of air helps me hear balance issues immediately.

The most major downside of headphones is translation to speakers.  You can make some crazy fun mixes that just don't translate.  I've tried the Canopener, Sonarworks, manual EQ, etc, and my best stuff is always a result of spending a lot of time referencing other mixes I know and love combined with a ton of car checks, speaker tests.

I can't wait for the day I have a space where I'm able to make noise, get some 310s and some treatment and stop chasing my tail and spend 3-4x the amount of time getting to where I want to go.  That's the hope anyway.

I'm not trying to deter anyone from getting started getting practice mixing in headphones, but it's definitely a stopgap for me and one I'm getting more and more fatigued by personally as the years go on.

author: spectrummasters
content: Along with others suggestions , I would advise some easy quick  tools to help you diagnose  . Izotope insight has a very good spectrograph that clearly reveals what’s happening down at 20-30 hz and how much energy is there . We ve also discussed izotope tonal balance here as well , but it’s really a very handy diagnostic when used to investigate where your low end energy is against a referenced track you like . Izotope Match eq is another tool that again allows you to compare and contrast what’s happening in your low end . I’ve also found the Shawn Everett trick mentioned here , useful for investigating low end (put a brick wall low pass filter on your mixbus and sweep it down to the 20-30hz with your subs on and see what that actually sounds and feels like . The other thing I find helpful is my gain staging and buses are set up so that I know how much gr and level should be arriving at each bus , so you soon know if you’re too hot just by looking at the comp / limiter . The last thing I’d say is know your speakers . I apply all this to myself because translation is my main point of focus right now . I forget where I heard it said , but I heard it said that the listener hears the inverse of what we the mixers hear .

author: spectrummasters
content:
....aw, found the old explanation of why....re: vu meter before the limiter and lufs after. 
This of course will be elementary stuff for everyone in here ...but might as well leave it here for a reminder/refresher. 

1. The VU meter to highlight how the mix is behaving pre-limiter :
VU (Volume Unit) Meters essentially display an average of what we hear, rather than the very fast peaks that we don’t. they will show you the energy in the low end, and if there is radical movement, then you probably have an issue with frequencies that you aren’t hearing.VU meters should “dance” smoothly and in a gentle manner, usually in time with the music, rather than in big jumps and erratic, out of time movement.  This erratic movement implies that there are drastic level changes, which will be hard to control in mastering and need addressing in the mix.  

2. The LUFS meter post limiter to set your loudness levels

Personally, i dont use this MO ...i like izotope tonal balance to monitor the mix but....just wanted to share what i rememmbered about people using vu ITB

author: Rollmottle
content: "Apple placed four microphones in its top-of-the-line AirPods Pro wireless earbuds. Two are used in the same way as those in the standard AirPods, for listening to the wearer's voice commands, allowing interaction with Siri, and for answering phone calls. The other two microphones are actually situated in the portion of the earbuds that fit inside the ear. Apple isn't trying to listen in on your internal conversation with this placement. Instead, these microphones hear the sound as it is formed by your ears and picks up on any leak-through from a less than ideal fit. This means the AirPods Pro don't adjust the sound to some theoretical model, but rather tune it specifically for each individual, and even to each ear."

author: Deleted User
content: I don’t measure, but the way I do it is to have a fixed reference at -23LUFS. I’m taking -23 reference tracks, turning my monitor controller to where it feels good (not too loud, not too quiet) and start mixing from there. Doing it this way means I have to take down my stems quite a lot at the beginning, but in return I can push things very drastically without clipping unintentionally. But you can take any reference you want, I just like to have loads of headroom at the start of a mix

Maybe something similar with spectral attenuation in RX. Might be worth leaning in this direction considering the EQ hasn’t been working 

If the song isn’t some 12 minute prog epic you could probably have something that feels great compared to the spectral dynamics in ~10 mins.

You said there’s two layers that make up the piano. The resonances could be due to the phase relationship between the notes/samples. maybe in a good place on some of em and a bad place on others. It's a difficult live recording, live drums with the wrong snare sound, the drummer hitting the cymbals hard, in an appartment living room, and 3 meters away, the singer.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
As long as we’re on the topic of finishing it’s worth saying that there are massive variations in people’s idea of what *done* is

For some mixers it’s “does this feel great?”, for some it’s a kind of polish/perfection, for someone like Alnini it was “does this represent what the band did in the live room?”, someone else might be chasing translation …

Someone mentioned that one upside of clients is they’ll (mostly) tell you when it’s done. But when you are on a solo project it’s worth giving some thought to what your definition of done is for the given mix

author: N
content:
I understand the perspective of (lufs don’t matter) however I want some consistency amongst my songs AND to be sufficiently loud compared to others.

I am competent of achieving very loud mixes however the introduction of artifacts bothers me. Usually I’m low passing with ISOL8 to listen for limiting/clipping clicks. These artifacts are unable to be heard unless I have a low pass filter active but I theorize that they, along with the extreme compression subconsciously degrade the listening experience by discretely assaulting your ears to the point of needing to take a break from listening. 

My music can be related sonically to clara la sans “another night” give or take more or less busy. (Keep in mind her stuff is cranked to the point of audible artifacts sitting around -7ish lufs integrated across the chorus).

I arrange the mix well and leave 1db of headroom for summing on individual instruments whilst they are loud enough for my target of -10 LUFi across the chorus, meaning my mix is actually 1db louder than -10 with space to sum on the pre master bus. Leaving headroom means I can introduce less artifacts at the cost of having to squeeze the dynamic range of individual instruments more than otherwise.

My issue is that If I want to aim for let’s say -8LUFSi across the chorus in a relatively clean way with minimal artifacts, I’m forced to squeeze the mix to -7.

I’d love to hear y’all thoughts on whether or not technically inaudible artifacts/distortion matter and whether or not it’s really worth for me to squeeze my mix 2db more in the name of competitive loudness?

Ps. Please bear with me as I am trying to figure this all out solo. Feel free to criticize my approach.
